Posts.Content: Congratulations!!! Well done for getting through this xxx
Posts.Title: I did it!! ðŸ˜œ

Posts.Content: Hiya. Sorry to hear you're having such a rough time. Sounds like you're being an absolute trooper. I'm starting tax tomorrow and not looking forward to it after the stories I've heard. I know its annoying when people say this but at least you have only one left of the nasty tax...hopefully fec will be kinder to you. I found it OK, nausea and fuzzy head was the worse once my anti-sickness were sorted. In stopped the cap after my second session as I had thinned so much it was way too cold. Best of luck, its horrible stuff but it works so keep being brave x
Posts.Title: New member of Breast Cancer group

Posts.Content: I'm totally with you on the detachment thing. I don't think it really hit me till the day I had my picc line in and the chemo talk from the nurses. Wore a wig all day today for the first time and it seems totally normal... Its so funny how we just learn to adjust. You will find good days and bad days, coming on this forum has been a massive help for me so hopefully will for you too. Take care x
Posts.Title: Feel like someone pressed the pause button!

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your news. I'm 32 with a 2 year old, and I also have grade 3 invasive ductal cancer. Mine is oestrogen and progesterone positive but her2 negative. I'm having my third cycle of fec on the 30th before starting 3 of taxotere. The chemo is bearable. I was really sick my first fec but they changed my anti-sickness and since then its been like having a bad hangover...fuzzy head and tiredness. Drink lots, rest and keep up your immune system and you will hopefully be OK. I used the cold cap and while my hair has thinned enough to need a wig I've kept a fair bit of it on top. You've come so far already, you can do this. The little ones help don't they...my little girl has been a trooper and absolutely nothing has phased her, not my picc or my bald bits nothing!! All the best. Xx
Posts.Title: New to this page! Diagnosed on 20th June aged 33!

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your news. I'm 32 with a 2 year old, and I also have grade 3 invasive ductal cancer. Mine is oestrogen and progesterone positive but her2 negative. Posts.Title: New to this page! Diagnosed on 20th June aged 33!

Posts.Content: I found a brand called Naked Care in my local boots that do a sensitive scalp variant. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: 26 years old, diagnosed with breast cancer, first chemo tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Chemo is going OK thanks, I'm taking the week immediately following the chemo off work, but finding that by the Friday I'm able to do a bit of housework and stuff. Â My husband helps with the little one on the first few days then I'm able to take care of her again with minimal support. Â I then go back to work (I work part time, 3.5 days a week) for two weeks until the next cycle starts.Â  I find that in the two weeks I'm back at work everything is pretty much back to normal, both in terms of how much I can do at work and in terms of running my household. Â I'm lucky as my husband is very hands on so I do have help. Â I get more tired than I normally would and I have had to stop running but I've kept up my yoga practise.Â  I know what you mean about cancer putting a stress on the marriage. Â We've been together 12 years but only got married at Christmas. Â It wasn't how we intended to start our first year of marriage! Â I think the key thing is to keep talking to each other so you know how you're each feeling and can talk it out. Â We also discussed having sessions with a councilor later on down the line if things get more difficult. Â  Keep in touch and let us know how you're getting on. Â XXX
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed :'( 35 years old

Posts.Content: Hi Mad dog, sorry you're having to go through all this. None of us want to be here but this forum is invaluable for support. There's also an under 50's Facebook group which is ace. I'm 32 with a husband and a two year old. I was diagnosed in June and have grade 3 invasive ductal. Stage not confirmed as I'm having chemo pre-surgery but they think stage 2. I'm half way through my chemo and its not been too bad. I have had three fec so far and side effects have been manageable with the support of my family. I've been really lucky I think. My biggest piece of advice to you would be to try and 'let go' as much as you can. I am a big control freak and worrier but this just isn't possible with cancer treatment. You have to take each day and each next step in the treatment process as it comes, without looking too far ahead. We have this disease and we can't change that but we're in expert hands and treatment these days is amazing. I've been so reassured by my drs and chemo nurses. I know what you mean about your husband's attitude. My hubby has been fab overall but was very depressed and withdrawn initially after diagosis. Others have been as you describe, I think that's a coping mechanism, act normal and minimise the fear because "it's nothing to worry about"... We didn't have any fertility treatment pre-chemo as there wasn't time. We had wanted more kids but we're coming around to the possibility this might not happen. My onco has said she thinks my periods will come back post-treatment and so after three years of tamoxifen we can discuss kids, but my cancer is extremely hormone receptor positive so it would be a big risk if any cells had been left behind. Will be thinking of you in the coming weeks, use your breast care nurse for any questions or anxieties....they are a font of knowledge, as are the ladies on here. All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed :'( 35 years old

Posts.Content: Thanks for the tip r.e. the Facebook group. Will see if there's one for my area. I'm 32 and have a two year old girl too. I'm having my third cycle of fec on Saturday, then three of tax after followed by surgery. I'm still at work too but have the week following chemo off to recover. I think you're right, staying up-beat really helps...you sound like you're doing amazingly well.
Posts.Title: 28years old with breast cancer!!!

Posts.Content: Thanks for posting! Its good to know how others are finding it as I wait to have my first session. Hope it keeps going well for you.
Posts.Title: First Chemo over

Posts.Content: I have the same 'glow' for the first few days after fec....its very common and a side effect of the drugs. You sound like you're doing brilliantly, and have an amazing attitude. Well done xxx
Posts.Title: Another side effect question

Posts.Content: I've just had my last fec yesterday and then three tax to go before surgery in the new year hopefully. I have grade 3 invasive ductal but luckily no node involvement. Wishing you all the best for your treatment xx
Posts.Title: Another side effect question
